metadata.title: Shoulder RC/SAPS 2025 Evidence Synthesis
metadata.description: Comprehensive evidence synthesis for rotator cuff tendinopathy, subacromial pain syndrome (SAPS), and post-operative rotator cuff repair rehabilitation, based on 2025 Dutch and international clinical guidelines
metadata.purpose: Provide CRISP agents with current best evidence for shoulder case clinical reasoning
source_documents: NOV/FMS Richtlijn SAPS 2025 (Nederlandse Orthopaedische Vereniging / Federatie Medisch Specialisten)
SNN Basisprotocol Rotator Cuff Repair (Samenwerkingsverband Nazorg Netwerk)
JOSPT Clinical Practice Guideline: Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy 2025
KNGF — No dedicated shoulder/SAPS guideline exists (gap noted)
metadata.usage_note: This synthesis integrates Dutch national guidelines with international evidence. KNGF guidelines do not cover shoulder pathology — NHG M08 and NOV/FMS SAPS serve as primary Dutch references.

kngf_gap.status: No dedicated KNGF guideline for shoulder complaints or SAPS
kngf_gap.implication: Physiotherapists must rely on NHG M08 (primary care pathway), NOV/FMS SAPS 2025 (specialist pathway), and international evidence (JOSPT 2025)
kngf_gap.coaching_note: Students should be aware that not all body regions have KNGF guidelines. Critical appraisal of available evidence from multiple sources is essential.

applicable_dutch_guidelines.key_relevance: Defines when to refer to physiotherapy vs specialist, initial management approach

applicable_dutch_guidelines.scope: Specialist-level diagnosis and management of subacromial pain syndrome
applicable_dutch_guidelines.role: Diagnostic approach, surgical indications, evidence-based treatment hierarchy
applicable_dutch_guidelines.key_relevance: 2025 update dismantles traditional test clusters, provides updated imaging and treatment recommendations

applicable_dutch_guidelines.scope: Post-operative rehabilitation protocol for rotator cuff repair
applicable_dutch_guidelines.role: Phase-based rehabilitation framework with timeline and criteria
applicable_dutch_guidelines.key_relevance: Baseline 6-week immobilization with progressive (4-week) and conservative (8-10 week) variants based on tear characteristics

international_evidence.guideline: JOSPT Clinical Practice Guideline: Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy 2025
international_evidence.scope: Conservative management of rotator cuff tendinopathy
international_evidence.key_relevance: 12-week imaging prohibition, exercise dosage, modality recommendations

conservative_management_rc_tendinopathy.definition: Rotator cuff tendinopathy encompasses a spectrum from reactive tendinopathy to tendon degeneration, presenting as shoulder pain with overhead activities, often within the subacromial space

classification.clinical_note: Subacute phase is critical window — yellow flags and chronicity risk factors should be actively assessed

diagnostic_approach_2025.key_change: NOV/FMS SAPS 2025 dismantles traditional orthopaedic test clusters
diagnostic_approach_2025.old_approach: Multiple special tests in cluster (Neer, Hawkins-Kennedy, Empty Can, Drop Arm, etc.) combined for diagnosis

rule_in_rc_tendinopathy.purpose: High specificity — positive result increases probability of RC involvement
rule_in_rc_tendinopathy.interpretation: Pain and/or weakness with resisted abduction in scaption with internal rotation

rule_out_rc_tendinopathy.purpose: High sensitivity — negative result effectively excludes subacromial involvement
rule_out_rc_tendinopathy.interpretation: Pain with passive internal rotation at 90° flexion

symptom_modification.purpose: Identify modifiable factors contributing to symptoms
examples: Scapular assistance test — does manual scapular repositioning reduce pain?
Thoracic extension modification — does improving thoracic posture reduce impingement symptoms?
Humeral head relocation — does posterior glide of humeral head during elevation reduce pain?
symptom_modification.clinical_value: Positive modification test directly informs intervention selection

diagnostic_approach_2025.coaching_note: Challenge students who perform >3 special tests for shoulder. Ask: what single test would most change your clinical reasoning?

imaging_policy_2025.jospt_recommendation: 12-week imaging prohibition before conservative management failure is established
rationale: Structural findings on imaging poorly correlate with symptoms
Asymptomatic rotator cuff tears are common (prevalence increases with age)
Early imaging may reinforce biomedical illness beliefs and catastrophizing
Imaging does not change initial conservative management approach
indications_for_imaging: Failure of 12+ weeks adequate conservative management
Red flags: suspected fracture, dislocation, tumor, infection
Acute traumatic onset with significant weakness (suspected acute full-thickness tear)
Pre-surgical planning (when surgery is being considered)
imaging_policy_2025.coaching_prompt: The patient requests an MRI at 4 weeks. What does the 2025 evidence say about imaging timing? How would you explain this to the patient?

recommended.description: Explain the nature of tendinopathy (not 'inflammation'), favorable prognosis with active management, hurt ≠ harm, activity modification (not cessation)
key_messages: Your tendon is not damaged — it is sensitized and needs graduated loading
Complete rest makes tendons weaker — controlled loading makes them stronger
Pain during exercise is acceptable if it settles within 24 hours
Recovery takes time (8-12 weeks minimum) but prognosis is good with consistent exercise

recommended.intervention: Progressive exercise therapy — graduated tendon loading
recommended.description: Isometric → isotonic → eccentric → functional loading progression

dosage.isometric_phase: 5x 45-second holds at ~70% max, 3x/day for reactive/high-irritability tendon
dosage.isotonic_phase: 3-4 sets x 8-12 reps, moderate load, every other day
dosage.eccentric_emphasis: 3 sets x 15 reps, slow eccentric (3-4 sec), daily or every other day
dosage.heavy_slow_resistance: 4 sets x 6-8 reps at high load, 3x/week (for chronic tendinopathy)
dosage.functional_loading: Sport/task-specific loading with progressive volume and intensity

recommended.progression_criteria: Pain ≤4/10 during exercise, no increase in resting pain lasting >24 hours, subjective improvement in function
recommended.coaching_prompt: What loading phase is appropriate for this patient's tendon irritability? How would you progress?

recommended.description: Address scapular dyskinesis contributing to subacromial narrowing
recommended.evidence: Moderate (supported by symptom modification test rationale)
exercises: Scapular setting (lower trapezius, serratus anterior activation)
Wall slides with scapular control focus
Prone Y, T, W exercises for posterior scapular musculature
Dynamic scapular control during functional overhead activities
recommended.coaching_prompt: Did you assess scapular contribution to symptoms? What did the scapular assistance test show?

recommended.description: Address thoracic kyphosis limiting shoulder flexion and contributing to impingement
recommended.indication: When thoracic extension modification test is positive

recommended.description: Screen for and address fear-avoidance, catastrophizing, low recovery expectations, work-related stress
recommended.evidence: Strong (extrapolated from MSK pain literature, supported by JOSPT 2025)
recommended.coaching_prompt: What yellow flags are present? How do they influence prognosis and your treatment approach?

conditionally_recommended.condition: Only as adjunct to exercise, not standalone
conditionally_recommended.rationale: May provide short-term pain relief facilitating exercise participation

conditionally_recommended.condition: NOT first-line. Only when pain prevents participation in exercise program
conditionally_recommended.caution: May suppress collagen synthesis and weaken tendon structure. Maximum 3 injections. Avoid in chronic tendinopathy.
conditionally_recommended.coaching_prompt: The GP has offered a corticosteroid injection. What are the pros and cons? When might it be appropriate?

not_recommended.rationale: Explicitly NOT recommended by JOSPT 2025 and NOV/FMS 2025. No evidence of benefit.
not_recommended.coaching_prompt: What does the 2025 evidence say about therapeutic ultrasound for shoulder tendinopathy?

not_recommended.rationale: Only indicated for calcific tendinopathy. NOT recommended for non-calcific RC tendinopathy.
not_recommended.exception: May be considered if calcific deposit confirmed on imaging and conservative management has failed

not_recommended.rationale: Not first-line treatment. Insufficient evidence for routine use in RC tendinopathy.
Not recommended for shoulder. Limited evidence, not first-line.
Must NOT be first-line for shoulder pain. Risk of dependence, no disease-modifying effect.
Promotes tendon deconditioning, delays recovery. Activity modification preferred over cessation.

primary: Full-thickness tear with significant functional limitation despite adequate conservative management (≥12 weeks)
Acute traumatic full-thickness tear in active individual

immobilization_protocol_tension_2025.critical_clinical_tension: Genuine disagreement between two authoritative Dutch protocols on immobilization duration

qualifying_criteria: Isolated supraspinatus involvement (no subscapularis or infraspinatus)
Good tissue quality (minimal fatty infiltration, Goutallier ≤2)
nov_2025_recommendation.evidence_basis: Early mobilization studies show equivalent re-tear rates (~9%) for small-to-medium tears with no difference in clinical outcomes
nov_2025_recommendation.rationale: Reduces stiffness risk, earlier functional recovery, maintained tendon healing

progressive.criteria: Small tear, good tissue quality, low stiffness risk profile
progressive.rationale: Reduces stiffness risk in patients with risk factors

conservative.criteria: Large/massive tear, poor tissue quality, revision surgery, subscapularis involvement
conservative.rationale: Extended protection for high re-tear risk repairs

immobilization_protocol_tension_2025.clinical_reasoning_challenge: For a patient with a medium isolated supraspinatus tear and good tissue quality, both the NOV (3 weeks) and SNN (6 weeks baseline, or 4 weeks progressive) could apply. The student must weigh: tissue healing biology, stiffness risk factors, patient characteristics, and surgeon preference.

small_to_medium_tears.conclusion: No significant difference — early mobilization appears safe

large_to_massive_tears.conclusion: Tear size is the key moderator of immobilization duration

immobilization_protocol_tension_2025.coaching_prompt: This patient's surgeon recommended 6 weeks in a sling. The NOV 2025 guideline suggests 3 weeks may be sufficient for this tear profile. How do you navigate this disagreement? What factors guide your decision?

phase_2_passive_assisted_rom.name: Passive/Active-Assisted ROM Phase
goals: Restore passive ROM (flexion, ER at 0° abduction)

dosage.initial: 3 sets x 10-15 reps, light resistance (theraband/light dumbbell)
dosage.progression: Increase resistance when 15 reps achieved with good form and no pain increase

phase_5_return_to_activity.name: Return to Activity/Sport Phase
goals: Full strength (≥80% of contralateral or pre-injury)
criteria_for_discharge: Able to perform all required work/sport tasks

first_line.rationale: Minimal systemic side effects, adequate for mild-moderate pain

second_line.caution: GI and cardiovascular risk with prolonged use. Consider gastroprotection.
second_line.rationale: Anti-inflammatory effect may help in reactive tendinopathy phase

not_first_line.rationale: Risk of dependence, no disease-modifying effect, may mask symptoms leading to overuse
Short-term pain relief only (4-8 weeks). May suppress collagen synthesis. Reserve for cases where pain prevents exercise participation.

primary_recommended.when_to_use: All shoulder conditions — primary outcome measure

primary_recommended.note: Already in clinimetrics database — essential for shoulder cases

psychosocial_screening.cutoff: >105 high risk of work disability, >130 very high risk
psychosocial_screening.when_to_use: Screening for chronicity risk in subacute MSK pain

key_clinical_tensions_for_debate.tension: Immobilization duration post-RC repair: NOV 3 weeks vs SNN 6 weeks
key_clinical_tensions_for_debate.context: For isolated supraspinatus, small-to-medium tear, good tissue quality

factors_to_weigh: Red flags that warrant early imaging

key_clinical_tensions_for_debate.tension: Corticosteroid injection: pain barrier vs tendon health
